body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     News             News       Click here to download a park newsletter (7.15MB).        Hawaiian seabird called ?Ua?u Photo by Jim Denny  **We need your help!**  Our native seabirds are fledging (flying to the ocean). They can become disoriented and end up on the ground unable to fly. If you find a grounded seabird anywhere on the island, please call 1-877-428-6911 (Haleakal? National Park Dispatch) to report the finding.      The Hawaiian Petrel (?Ua?u) is an endangered species. Its largest known nesting colony is located at the top of Mt. Haleakal?. For more information on the Hawaiian Petrel, click here.         **Protect our state bird!** N?n?, Hawaiian Geese, are nesting in the park. They are ground nesters and will aggressively defend their nests. Please support their health and safety in the following ways: Do not approach them, do not feed them, and stay on trail. If a nene is acting aggressively toward you, simply walk away.
